title: Difficult to break down funding: Qld A-G
text:
Queensland's Attorney-General says it's too difficult to determine how much legal aid funding has been paid to a law firm owned by a fellow government MP.

Toohey MP Peter Russo has been questioned about his law firm receiving funding from the state's legal services body in parliament for the second day in a row.

Mr Russo has denied allegations of a potential conflict of interest and explained his position as head of parliament's Legal Affairs Committee has no role in determining the budget for Legal Aid Queensland.

He also tabled a letter on Tuesday from the Clerk which said "I do not see how (Mr Russo is) conflicted", and his own independent legal advice.

On Wednesday Attorney-General Yvette D'Ath fielded a question from Opposition MP David Janetzki, who asked about how much taxpayer money had been paid to Mr Russo's firm since his election in 2015.

Ms D'ath said the the Opposition had asked similar questions in the past and learned Legal Aid could not give funding breakdowns "because of the amount of work required in relation to the information being sought".

She noted the only way the opposition was able to ask questions of Mr Russo's firm was because of public disclosures made by Mr Russo and Legal Aid.

"Of these allegations of cover-up and everything else, it was so covered up that it was in the public register," Ms D'Ath said.

Also on Wednesday, Queensland Health Minister Steven Miles announced a push to put an end to children and teens inhaling dangerous household chemicals.

Queensland health officials are expected to meet with consumer goods giant Unilever and retailers to end the issue which has seen almost 100 people, many children and teenagers, admitted to hospital in the past year.
